Title.evidence: Importance: Acute normovolemic hemodilution (ANH) is a well-known blood conservation technique, yet its adoption in the US remains low (<20%), and cardiac surgery remains the largest consumer of blood components.

Trial_Design.evidence: Design, Setting, and Participants: A retrospective propensity–score matched cohort study using data from the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) Adult Cardiac Surgery Database (version 4.20.2).

Participants.evidence: The study included adult patients (≥18 years) undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and/or valve surgery with CPB (July 2020 to September 2023).

Intervention.evidence: Exposure: The primary exposure was ANH, defined as any recorded use/volume in the STS database.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To evaluate ANH use in perioperative transfusion and blood component use in patients undergoing surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).

Method_Outcome.evidence: Main Outcome and Measures: The primary outcome was intraoperative or postoperative transfusion of any blood component.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Results: Among 16 795 patients (mean [SD] age, 65.3 [10.5] years; 12 114 male [72.1%]), ANH was reported in 2463 cases (14.7%).

Number_Analysed.evidence: After propensity score matching (n = 2282 pairs), transfusion rates were significantly lower in the ANH group (31.2% vs 36.4%; P < .001).

Result_Outcome.evidence: ANH was associated with 27% lower odds of any transfusion (odds ratio, 0.73; 95% CI, 0.60-0.89).
